<ce:para view="all">The mechanism of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> formation is presumably multistage and sophisticated. A probable description is proposed below. It should be outlined that different stages of the synthesis most likely overlap and are not necessary consecutive. However, in order to simplify the discussion we give them formally as a set of separated processes. The first stage is the reduction of KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> by CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH accompanied by partial deprotonation of en·2HCl (
<ce:float-anchor refid="fig3"></ce:float-anchor>, (1)). This reaction is finished within first 2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>min of the synthesis, which is registered by the formation of a voluminous brown precipitate, presumably MnO<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>, and the solution decolouration. 1.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of CH<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O, which is a crucial reagent in the subsequent processes, forms per 1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mol of <mml:math altimg="si5.gif" overflow="scroll">
<mml:mrow>
<mml:msubsup>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mtext>MnO</mml:mtext>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mn>4</mml:mn>
</mml:mrow>
<mml:mrow>
<mml:mo>-</mml:mo>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:msubsup>
</mml:mrow>
</mml:math>.</ce:para><ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>1</ce:bold>. The mixture of cobalt powder (0.07<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), KMnO<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf> (0.2<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 1.25<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), ethylenediamine dihydrochloride (0.33<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), (NH<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>)<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>C<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">4</ce:inf>·H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O (0.36<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g, 2.5<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mmol), CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) were placed in a 50<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL conic flask. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 50–60<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>°C in open air for 8<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>h until the total dissolution of Co was observed. The crude complex precipitated during the reaction was filtered off, washed with 2-propanol and dried in vacuo at room temperature. Recrystallization from H<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>O gave orange crystals suitable for X-ray single crystal analysis. Yield 0.23<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (30% by cobalt). Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">13</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">33</ce:inf>CoMnClN<ce:inf loc="post">7</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">11</ce:inf>: C, 25.48; H, 5.43; N, 16.00; Cl, 5.79; Co, 9.62; Mn, 8.97. Found: C, 25.2; H, 5.2; N, 15.9; Cl, 5.6; Co, 9.5; Mn, 8.8. IR (KBr discs, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3420br, 3247sh, 3216m, 3120br, 2989sh, 2906w, 2866w, 1620vs, 1468sh, 1446m, 1352m, 1315s, 1276w, 1242w, 1165m, 1136w, 1053m, 1018w, 981m, 906w, 840m, 783m, 713m, 609w, 586w, 499w, 445w.</ce:simple-para><ce:simple-para view="all">Synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold>. The synthesis of <ce:bold>2</ce:bold> was carried out similarly to <ce:bold>1</ce:bold> using dmf (20<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL) as a solvent but with addition of 0.1<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>mL of CH<ce:inf loc="post">3</ce:inf>OH as reducing agent. Yield 0.38<ce:hsp sp="0.25"></ce:hsp>g (27% by cobalt). Calc. for C<ce:inf loc="post">22</ce:inf>H<ce:inf loc="post">60</ce:inf>Co<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>Mn<ce:inf loc="post">2</ce:inf>N<ce:inf loc="post">12</ce:inf>O<ce:inf loc="post">26</ce:inf>: C, 23.25; H, 5.32; N, 14.79; Co, 10.37; Mn, 9.67. Found: C, 23.2; H, 5.2; N, 14.6; Co, 10.3; Mn, 9.6. IR (KBr discs, cm<ce:sup loc="post">–1</ce:sup>): 3500m, 3427m, 3204m, 3150sh, 3092m, 2967w, 1684sh, 1656s, 1618s, 1579sh, 1554m, 1461w, 1420m, 1369w, 1343w, 1335m, 1318sh, 1284m, 1247w, 1190w, 1157w, 1120w, 1055m, 995w, 880w, 780m, 774m, 578w, 495m, 437w.</ce:simple-para>
clean_text:
The mechanism of 1 formation is presumably multistage and sophisticated. A probable description is proposed below. It should be outlined that different stages of the synthesis most likely overlap and are not necessary consecutive. However, in order to simplify the discussion we give them formally as a set of separated processes. The first stage is the reduction of KMnO4 by CH3OH accompanied by partial deprotonation of en⋅2HCl ( , (1)). This reaction is finished within first 2min of the synthesis, which is registered by the formation of a voluminous brown precipitate, presumably MnO2, and the solution decolouration. 1.5mol of CH2O, which is a crucial reagent in the subsequent processes, forms per 1mol of     MnO   4   -    .

Synthesis of 1. The mixture of cobalt powder (0.07g, 1.25mmol), KMnO4 (0.2g, 1.25mmol), ethylenediamine dihydrochloride (0.33g, 2.5mmol), (NH4)2C2O4⋅H2O (0.36g, 2.5mmol), CH3OH (20mL) were placed in a 50mL conic flask. The reaction mixture was magnetically stirred at 50-60°C in open air for 8h until the total dissolution of Co was observed. The crude complex precipitated during the reaction was filtered off, washed with 2-propanol and dried in vacuo at room temperature. Recrystallization from H2O gave orange crystals suitable for X-ray single crystal analysis. Yield 0.23g (30% by cobalt). Calc. for C13H33CoMnClN7O11: C, 25.48; H, 5.43; N, 16.00; Cl, 5.79; Co, 9.62; Mn, 8.97. Found: C, 25.2; H, 5.2; N, 15.9; Cl, 5.6; Co, 9.5; Mn, 8.8. IR (KBr discs, cm-1): 3420br, 3247sh, 3216m, 3120br, 2989sh, 2906w, 2866w, 1620vs, 1468sh, 1446m, 1352m, 1315s, 1276w, 1242w, 1165m, 1136w, 1053m, 1018w, 981m, 906w, 840m, 783m, 713m, 609w, 586w, 499w, 445w.

Synthesis of 2. The synthesis of 2 was carried out similarly to 1 using dmf (20mL) as a solvent but with addition of 0.1mL of CH3OH as reducing agent. Yield 0.38g (27% by cobalt). Calc. for C22H60Co2Mn2N12O26: C, 23.25; H, 5.32; N, 14.79; Co, 10.37; Mn, 9.67. Found: C, 23.2; H, 5.2; N, 14.6; Co, 10.3; Mn, 9.6. IR (KBr discs, cm-1): 3500m, 3427m, 3204m, 3150sh, 3092m, 2967w, 1684sh, 1656s, 1618s, 1579sh, 1554m, 1461w, 1420m, 1369w, 1343w, 1335m, 1318sh, 1284m, 1247w, 1190w, 1157w, 1120w, 1055m, 995w, 880w, 780m, 774m, 578w, 495m, 437w.
